title: Blues Scale & Improvisation
description: Learn the blues scale and the 12-bar blues structure for improvising.

steps.title: The Blues Scale
steps.description: The blues scale is a minor pentatonic scale with one extra note — the 'blue note' (flat 5th). In C, the notes are: C, Eb, F, F#, G, Bb. The blue note (F#) creates the characteristic tension and emotion of blues music.

steps.title: Play the C Blues Scale
steps.description: Play the 6 notes of the C blues scale: C, Eb, F, F#/Gb, G, Bb.
steps.hint: The blue note (F#/Gb) is between F and G.

steps.title: The 12-Bar Blues
steps.description:
The 12-bar blues is the most common structure in blues, rock, and jazz. It's 12 bars long using three chords (I, IV, V):

• Bars 1-4: I chord (C)
• Bars 5-6: IV chord (F)
• Bars 7-8: I chord (C)
• Bar 9: V chord (G)
• Bar 10: IV chord (F)
• Bars 11-12: I chord (C)

You can improvise over this using the blues scale!

steps.title: The I Chord: C7
steps.description: In blues, we often use dominant 7th chords. Play a C chord (the I chord).
steps.hint: C + E + G (60, 64, 67). In blues, you'd add Bb for a C7.

steps.title: The IV Chord: F
steps.description: Play the F chord (IV chord in the key of C).

steps.title: The V Chord: G
steps.description: Play the G chord (V chord). This creates tension that resolves back to C.

steps.title: Blues Improvisation Tips
steps.description:
When improvising blues:

• Bend into the blue note (F#) from below — slide up from F
• Use call-and-response: play a phrase, pause, then 'answer' it
• End phrases on C or G for stability
• Mix short punchy notes with long held notes
• Don't be afraid of silence — space is powerful

The blues scale works over ALL three chords in a 12-bar blues. That's the beauty of it!
